title: Systems in Rust
text:
CS 271 â€œSystems in Rustâ€

Called:

CS 271: Systems Programming
CS 271: Sys Programming, Computer Arch

The first semester class in a:

Compiled language, with
No garbage collector.

Term these â€œsystemsâ€ languages.

Suitable to write an operating system.

Taught this year in Rust.

So to me, â€œSystems in Rustâ€



MW 1310-1440


Prof.Â Calvin

title: Welcome
text:
Welcome to Systems in Rust

What is in point of fact a systems cryptography course.
But itâ€™s in Rust so you have to take it.

Action Items:

Access the course webpage
Join the Discord!

You should have gotten an emailâ€¦

Set up Linux/Rust/Git.

title: Welcome
text:
The Great Work

Thesis Title

Mining Secure Behavior of Hardware Designs

Plain English

Just as there are bugs in code that makes software, modern hardware is also written in code and therefore may contain bugs. I find these bugs.

title: Welcome
text:
Course Format

Lecture Monday
Lab Wednesday
Homework due Friday 1440 PM ET
In-class midterm week of 10/06
Final project due whenever the final is scheduled.

title: Welcome
text:
Ungrading++

Your voices have been heard: > I think failing my systems class was the best thing that happened to me.


This course demanded strong self-motivation due to its lax grading standards, which I did not bring to the table. Thus, I didnâ€™t learn as much as I mightâ€™ve if grading mattered more.

title: Welcome
text:
Proposal

I will offer two option

Ungrading
Specification Grading

Vote as a class (anonymously)
I update syllabus before add/drop ends.

title: Welcome
text:
1. Ungrading

I provide autograders for all assignments except final.

Or a reference solution with a rubric, if automated testing is too weird.
I will have a final reference solution but will at most share snippets individually.

You do whatever you want.
Enrolled students get an A.

title: Welcome
text:
2. Specification Grading

All the rage. I was never fan but tell me what you think.
Basically, I will assign some stuff but you donâ€™t have to do all of it perfectly.

No partial credit, everything is yes/no grading.

I took distributions over final, midterm, and Lab/HW

title: Welcome
text:
Final

Create, document, and publish a self-hosting version control system.
Entire codebase in Rust.
Minimum specifications:

Support nested directory structures.
Support text-based files (.rs, .py, .txt)
Allow reverting to named changes (commits).
Completed by you and at most a partner.

title: Welcome
text:
Late Work Policy

Late work is not accepted.

Turning in anything at all for on 90% of assignments yields B.
Miss 100% of assignments and midterm but do the final for an A.

title: Welcome
text:
AI Policy

I would be shocked if it is helpful to you.
If you think it is helpful, that is probably not a good sign.
You can use it (I wouldnâ€™t)

title: Welcome
text:
Collaboration Policy

Non-final:

Any size group via enthusiastic consent.
Turn in your own code/copy.

Final:

Partners via enthusiastic consent.
Turn in your own code/copy.

title: Welcome
text:
Vote

If thereâ€™s not a Forms link here I should add one quickly.

title: Welcome
text:
The Hard Part

After ~10 years of systems research Iâ€™ve convinced myself only two things really matter:

Pointers, and
Recursion

Recursion isnâ€™t too badâ€¦

>>> exp = lambda b, n : b if n == 1 else b*exp(b,n-1)
>>> exp(2,8)
256

title: Welcome
text:
Pointers

Pointers are a beast, but without them nothing makes sense!



>>> x = 1
>>> def addx():
...     x += 1
...
>>> addx()
UnboundLocalError:
<blah blah blah error messages>

>>> x = [1]
>>> def addx():
...     x[0] += 1
...
>>> addx()
>>> x
[2]

title: Welcome
text:
Insight

Definition:

Pointers: Variables that store memory addresses.
Recursion: Functions calling themselves to solve sub-problems.

Importance:

Core to efficient algorithms and memory management in low-level programming.

title: Welcome
text:
Python and Pointers

Why not .py (.js, .java, .cs, .cpp, etc)?

These languages abstract memory.
This abstraction makes computation unclear
This lack of clarity:

Adversely impacts education
Complicates low-level design
Leads to low performance

Good languages (except Java) but not for us

title: Welcome
text:
Rust and Pointers

Rust:

Obscures pointers, butâ€¦
Does not obscure memory.

This is good!

Memory matters, but pointers are historical accident.

You should probably use Rust in every application where correctness or performance matters.

title: Welcome
text:
Rust and Recursion

Separately, Rust is built on one of the most exciting ongoing computer science research efforts:
LLVM (stands for LLVM)
Basically, a way of turning human-readable code into machine-executable code.

Very good at turning recursion into iteration and/or vice versa.

So Rust experiences less costs on recursion than many other languages.

title: Welcome
text:
Git

If you donâ€™t know git, you should soon.
Git corresponds, like the others, to a command: git

It is common now to use other techniques, but the command remains extremely stable

Quoth GitHub, the first and greatest of the collaboration tools:


If you want a lot of control and flexibility, you can use the command line.

title: Welcome
text:
Git Example

So basically, you have things called repositories or â€œreposâ€

title: Welcome
text:
Visually





flowchart LR
  B(Wordle)
  B --> C(SHA512)
  C --> D(Ed25519)
  B --> F(Graphs)
  C --> H(Merkle)
  F --> H
  F --> G(LCS)
  H --> I(VCS)
  G --> I
  D --> I







LCS = Longest common subsequence, like diff
VCS = Version Control System, like git

title: Welcome
text:
SHA

SHA Basics:

Cryptographic hash function family.
Input data into fixed-size hash values.

Use Cases:

Data integrity.

Learning Objectives:

Reason about bits and bytes.

title: Welcome
text:
Ed25519

Ed25519 Basics:

Public-key signature system.
Based on elliptic curve cryptography (specifically, Edwards curves).
Uses SHA-512 and Curve25519.

Use Cases:

Confidentiality and authentication.

Learning Objectives:

Reason about numerical computing.

title: Welcome
text:
Graphs

Introduce graphs as a way to:

Organize files
Compare files
Track changes.

title: Welcome
text:
Longest Common Subseq. (LCS)

LCS Basics:

Find longest sequence of characters in the same relative order in two or more sequences, but not necessarily contiguously.
Often solved using dynamic programming.

Use Cases:

File comparison (e.g., diff utility).

Learning Objectives:

Linear data structure.

title: Welcome
text:
Merkle Trees

Merkle Trees:

Tree structure using SHA for data integrity.
Hashes stored as nodes; pointers link them.
Leaf nodes are RSA signatures!

Merkle Trees are balanced

Hierarchical data structure embedded in linear data structure.

title: Welcome
text:
File System

The file system a tree that cannot (easily) be embedded in a linear data structure.

title: Welcome
text:
Vim

You should use vim or another console-based editor as a component of your learning in this class.
This will not be assessed (how can it be) but will likely be expected in a non-trivial subset of settings this course material will be useful.
I will live-code in either vim or helix

Recursion: Functions calling themselves to solve sub-problems.

Importance:

Core to efficient algorithms and memory management in low-level programming.

title: Welcome
text:
Python and Pointers

Why not .py (.js, .java, .cs, .cpp, etc)?

These languages abstract memory.
This abstraction makes computation unclear
This lack of clarity:

Adversely impacts education
Complicates low-level design
Leads to low performance

Good languages (except Java) but not for us

title: Welcome
text:
Rust and Pointers

Rust:

Obscures pointers, butâ€¦
Does not obscure memory.

This is good!

Memory matters, but pointers are historical accident.

You should probably use Rust in every application where correctness or performance matters.

title: Welcome
text:
Rust and Recursion

Separately, Rust is built on one of the most exciting ongoing computer science research efforts:
LLVM (stands for LLVM)
Basically, a way of turning human-readable code into machine-executable code.

Very good at turning recursion into iteration and/or vice versa.

So Rust experiences less costs on recursion than many other languages.

title: Welcome
text:
Git

If you donâ€™t know git, you should soon.
Git corresponds, like the others, to a command: git

It is common now to use other techniques, but the command remains extremely stable

Quoth GitHub, the first and greatest of the collaboration tools:


If you want a lot of control and flexibility, you can use the command line.

title: Welcome
text:
Git Example

So basically, you have things called repositories or â€œreposâ€

title: Welcome
text:
Visually





flowchart LR
  B(Wordle)
  B --> C(SHA512)
  C --> D(Ed25519)
  B --> F(Graphs)
  C --> H(Merkle)
  F --> H
  F --> G(LCS)
  H --> I(VCS)
  G --> I
  D --> I







LCS = Longest common subsequence, like diff
VCS = Version Control System, like git

title: Welcome
text:
SHA

SHA Basics:

Cryptographic hash function family.
Input data into fixed-size hash values.

Use Cases:

Data integrity.

Learning Objectives:

Reason about bits and bytes.

title: Welcome
text:
Ed25519

Ed25519 Basics:

Public-key signature system.
Based on elliptic curve cryptography (specifically, Edwards curves).
Uses SHA-512 and Curve25519.

Use Cases:

Confidentiality and authentication.

Learning Objectives:

Reason about numerical computing.

title: Welcome
text:
Graphs

Introduce graphs as a way to:

Organize files
Compare files
Track changes.

title: Welcome
text:
Longest Common Subseq. (LCS)

LCS Basics:

Find longest sequence of characters in the same relative order in two or more sequences, but not necessarily contiguously.
Often solved using dynamic programming.

Use Cases:

File comparison (e.g., diff utility).

Learning Objectives:

Linear data structure.

title: Welcome
text:
Merkle Trees

Merkle Trees:

Tree structure using SHA for data integrity.
Hashes stored as nodes; pointers link them.
Leaf nodes are RSA signatures!

Merkle Trees are balanced

Hierarchical data structure embedded in linear data structure.

title: Welcome
text:
File System

The file system a tree that cannot (easily) be embedded in a linear data structure.

title: Welcome
text:
Vim

You should use vim or another console-based editor as a component of your learning in this class.
This will not be assessed (how can it be) but will likely be expected in a non-trivial subset of settings this course material will be useful.
I will live-code in either vim or helix

title: Rustup
text:
Announcements

Lab Day

Set up environment

title: Rustup
text:
Homework

The first homework, â€œHi worldâ€, is ready after this class.

It is comically trivial.
Mostly makes sure you have everything set up.

Due Friday, 1 Sept.Â at 1440 ET.

title: Rustup
text:
Today

Set up your operating system, if it is not UNIX-based.
Install Rust.
Install Git
Bonus!

Install Vim, Neovim, or Helix.

title: Rustup
text:
Windows

Windows usage is not supported in the course.
If you are using Windows, you must:

Use Windows Subsystem for Linux (Recommended)
Use Docker or Podman
Use Git Bash or Mingw in some other way (Discouraged)
Use Cygwin (Discouraged)

title: Rustup
text:
MacOS

MacOS should mostly work out-of-the-box.
You need one thing: XCode

title: Rustup
text:
Rustup

On your UNIX-based OS:

Linux
MacOS
WSL 2
FreeBSD

Open the command line and run the following:

curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 https://sh.rustup.rs -sSf | sh

Read more

title: Rustup
text:
Verify

To ensure you have a Rust installation, run:

rustc --version

At time of slide creation, I saw this version:

rustc 1.87.0 (17067e9ac 2025-05-09)

title: Rustup
text:
Git Installation

Ensure you have a Git installation:

Windows:

Launch WSL

wsl ~

Install git within WSL

sudo apt install git
MacOS:

Launch the terminal and then:

xcode-select --install

title: Rustup
text:
Verify

Verify install via:

git --version

I had:

git version 2.34.1

title: Rustup
text:
Account

Ensure you have an account on GitHub.
Read More

title: Rustup
text:
Windows

Windows usage is not supported in the course.
If you are using Windows, you must:

Use Windows Subsystem for Linux (Recommended)
Use Docker or Podman
Use Git Bash or Mingw in some other way (Discouraged)
Use Cygwin (Discouraged)




WSL 2

Windows Subsystem for Linux
Follow this guide
Notes:

Use WSL 2. It is the default.
I recommend using Ubuntu distribution. You will be asked.
I prefer Windows Terminal.

Windows key -> â€œTerminalâ€ -> Enter
Type wsl






Docker or Podman

Both will require WSL 2, but install for you
Docker has better Windows support, I believe Podman is seeing more use.
Follow this guide.
Notes:

Use WSL 2 backend.
You are responsible for teaching yourself containers.
Slides for last year.





Git Bash

I have set up guide for Git Bash for another course
This seemed like it could work. I wonâ€™t be checking.




Cygwin

I have no idea how Cygwin works but itâ€™s pretty cool.
Basically no longer in use due to WSL 2 and Docker.
Follow this guide
